pr_title: Refactor(e2e): Run Android tests on Azure Devops emulators instead of AppCenter

timeline.message:
Refactor(e2e): Run Android tests on Azure Devops emulators instead of AppCenter

Consolidating all th Android runners that used to be divided into ___DeviceAndroidRunner and ___ModuleAndroidRunner into just ___AndroidRunner.

timeline.bodyText: This timeout was simply too long. Any test timeout failures will be caught in the first 30 seconds
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: Do we have any long running tests? Token refresh tests? Connection status change tests?
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

timeline.bodyText: Is this really a "dummy"? Else we might want to rename it to something else
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Sure, I can rename this to "Fake"
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: It exists only so that, if all other tests get filtered, at least one test runs. Android instrumentation testing fails if no tests run, counterintuitively
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: q - we need fewer test groups now because...? can we parallelize more stuff in the android emulator, or do we spin up more emulators?
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: We used to have separate test groups for device and module tests. For instance, we had a SendMessagesDeviceAndroidRunner and a SendMessagesModuleAndroidRunner, but now those two are combined into just SendMessagesAndroidRunner. On top of that, several test groups contained only a few tests, so they were also grouped together instead of given their own test group
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: RegistryManager tests and Service Client tests, for instance, don't need their own test group anymore. They can share
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Does TestSuite annotation work better with emulators? That way we wouldn't need a fakeTest class and a lot of other overhead code.
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: We do still need this. We added this fake test class for App Center, but they share the same problem as running the test on an emulator. Anytime you invoke instrumentation tests on an android device, emulator or real, at least one test needs to run. Otherwise it will report an error
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: Sure, but with TestSuite, instead of multiple runners, we can have a single runner that references all the test files, and does the initial setup.
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: I don't see how we could split the tests into groups with this approach
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: This test was failing on android in particular at some point, but it was never re-enabled
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: File upload as a whole wasn't being tested on Android, but not on purpose. I'd re-enable it but there are some test failures on Android. They appear to be test bugs, not bugs in file upload itself. I'll open a separate PR to fix that bug, and to re-enable file upload tests on android
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: I assume this cleanup is happening elsewhere now?
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Actually, this looks like it shouldn't have been deleted. I'll revert this
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Q - don't we have tests that take in the SSL context directly, or do they have a specific test class?
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: We do have a single test for that in the SendMessages test suite
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: For context, the SSLContext constructor was a very recent addition, and most of these tests were written before then.
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: nit: It would help if these constructors and parameterized test methods have some comments that describe what they do. I know this has been a point of confusion for me in the past, because these tests have pretty deep inheritance, and the test class and method names are not descriptive of what they are responsible for.
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Sure thing, I can add some comments. I plan on removing the JVMRunner classes and moving their logic into the test classes themselves to help cut down on the inheritance.
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: This effort will be in a different PR, since removing the JVMRunner classes is a big task
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: MQTT_WS does support x509 auth now. It's orthogonal to this PR, but worth enabling
replies.author: timtay-microsoft
